questions.text: A middle aged immunocompromised male came with fever and breathlessness. HRCT showed a middle lobe lesion with infiltration. Lung biopsy from the lesion is shown in the image below. What will be the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

CMV pneumonia The given clinical scenario and histopathological image showing presence of intranuclear inclusions ( owl eyes inclusions) in the lung biopsy in an immunocompromised patient suggests the diagnosis of CMV pneumonia. CMV (Cytomegalovirus) pneumonia is commonly seen in immunocompromised individuals, such as the middle-aged immunocompromised male described in the scenario. CMV is a member of the herpesvirus family and can cause opportunistic infections in individuals with weakened immune systems. The presence of fever, breathlessness, and an infiltrative middle lobe lesion on HRCT are consistent with CMV pneumonia. https://images.app.goo.gl/CJunpk2D1GocAT4m8

Highyeild:

questions.text: Which of the following malignancy is least commonly associated with lymphatic spread?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Basal cell carcinoma

Highyeild:

Basal cell carcinoma is a locally aggressive cutaneous tumor . It is associated with mutations activating the Hedgehog pathway signaling . Metastasis is very rare . Histologically, the tumor cells resemble the normal basal cell layer of the epidermis , which arise from the epidermis or follicular epithelium. BCC does NOT occur on mucosal surfaces . The cells at the periphery of the tumor cell islands are arranged radially with their long axes in parallel alignment ( palisading ). Basal cell carcinomas usually present as pearly papule s containing prominent dilated subepidermal blood vessels ( telangiectasias ). Some tumors contain melanin and superficially resemble melanocytic nevi or melanomas . Advanced lesions may ulcerate , and extensive local invasion of bone or facial sinuses may occur after many years of neglect or in unusually aggressive tumors, explaining the archaic designation of rodent ulcers . One common and important variant, the superficial basal cell carcinoma , presents as an erythematous, occasionally pigmented plaque that may resemble early forms of melanoma .

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B. Squamous cell carcinoma. Incorrect , hamartoma is abnormal tissue at normal site . Option: C. Malignant melanoma. Incorrect , Hydatidiform mole or molar pregnancy is benign tumor of trophoblastic cell . Option: D. Merkel cell carcinoma. Incorrect , Chondroma is benign tumor of cartilaginous tissue .

Extraedge:

All malignant tumors can metastasize, but some do so very infrequently. Examples include malignant neoplasms of the glial cells in the central nervous system, called gliomas, and basal cell carcinomas of the skin, both of which invade early in their course but rarely metastasize.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy had a cut in his forearm 4 days ago. Now the bleeding has been stopped due to granulation tissue formation. While taking a skin biopsy a part of the granulation tissue was also included in the specimen. The histology of granulation tissue is shown below. Which type of collagen is found in this granulation tissue?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Type 3

Highyeild:

Granulation tissues fill in the gaps of the wound and provide the underlying framework for the regrowth of tissue epithelium . During wound healing, first a provisional matrix containing fibrin, plasma fibronectin, and type III collagen is formed , but in about 2 weeks this is replaced by a matrix composed primarily of type I collagen . Collagens are composed of three separate polypeptide chains braided into a ropelike triple helix. About 30 collagen types have been identified, some of which are unique to specific cells and tissues. Few common types are given in the following table: Collagen type Localization I Skin, bone, tendons. most abundant collagen II Vitreous body, cartilage III Granulation tissue, reticulin of skin, blood vessels, uterus IV Basement membrane VII Dermo-epidermal junction in skin VIII Descemet membrane in eye Wound contraction helps close the wound by decreasing the gap between its dermal edges and reducing the wound surface area. Hence it is an important feature in healing by the secondary union . Wound contraction involves forming a network of myofibroblasts , which are modified fibroblasts with contractile properties .

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A: Type 1. Incorrect , predominant collagen seen at >2 weeks of wound healing. Option B: Type 2. Incorrect , predominant collagen seen in cartilage. Option D: Type 4. Incorrect , predominant collagen seen in Basement membrane.

Extraedge:

Excessive scarring: Excessive formation of the components of the repair process can give rise to hypertrophic scars and keloids . These often grow rapidly and contain abundant myofibroblasts , but they tend to regress over several months ( Hypertrophic scar ) or do not regress ( Keloid ).

options.label: A
options.text: Rolling—Stable adhesion—Activation of integrins—Migration via endothelium

questions.correct_answer: B. Rolling—Activation of integrins—Stable adhesion—Migration via endothelium
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Rolling—Activation of integrins—Stable adhesion—Migration via endothelium

Highyeild:

Acute inflammation has three major components: Dilation of small vessels Increased permeability of the microvasculature that leads to plasma proteins and leukocytes to leave the circulation Emigration of the leukocytes from the microcirculation. The changes in blood flow and vascular permeability are quickly followed by an influx of leukocytes into the tissue. The journey of leukocytes from the vessel lumen to the tissue is a multistep process that is mediated and controlled by adhesion molecules and cytokines called chemokines . The processes involved are as follows: In the lumen- Margination Rolling Activation of integrin Adhesion to endothelium Followed by migration across the endothelium and vessel wall and migration in the tissues toward a chemotactic stimulus .

questions.text: A 5-year-old child was presenting with proptosis. Microscopic examination of the mass has revealed a round cell tumor positive for Desmin immunohistochemical marker. Most likely diagnosis would be:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma Based on the provided information, the most likely diagnosis for a 5-year-old child presenting with proptosis and a round cell tumor positive for the Desmin immunohistochemical marker would be Embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma.

Highyeild:

Rhabdomyosarcoma It is a malignant mesenchymal tumor with skeletal muscle differentiation. Three subtypes: Alveolar (20%), Embryonal (60%), and Pleomorphic (20%) Embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma: The tumor cells mimic skeletal muscle at various stages of embryogenesis and consist of sheets of both primitive round and spindled cells in a myxoid stroma. Immunohistochemistry for desmin and myogenin confirms the rhabdomyoblastic differentiation.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A .Leukemia: It typically presents with hematological abnormalities rather than localized masses like proptosis. Option C. Lymphoma: It usually presents with lymph node involvement or systemic symptoms, rather than isolated proptosis. Option D .Primitive Neuroectodermal Tumor (PNET): It is a type of malignant tumor that arises from embryonic nerve cells. While it can occur in children, it does not typically present with proptosis, and Desmin staining is not characteristic of PNET.

questions.text: Which among the following laboratory investigations is best to reveal about bleeding in disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC)?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Increased FDPs Two types of DIC are acute (decompensated) and chronic (compensated). In acute DIC , there is rapid activation of coagulation leading to bleeding from consumption of coagulation factors . Findings in acute DIC are low platelet, prolonged PT and APTT, low fibrinogen, and increased FDP and D-dimer . In chronic DIC , there is slow activation of coagulation with slow consumption of coagulation factors . Findings are normal platelet count, normal PT and APTT . However, FDP and D-dimer are increased . So in acute DIC, all the four options are correct , while if we consider the question as chronic DIC, then the best possible answer is increased FDP .

Highyeild:

Venous Thrombosis: Most venous thrombi occur in the superficial or deep veins of the leg . Superficial venous thrombi typically occur in the saphenous veins in the setting of varicosities . Such thrombi can cause local congestion, swelling, pain, and tenderness, but rarely embolize, but predispose the overlying skin to develop infection and ulcers (varicose ulcers) . Deep venous thrombosis (DVT) involving one of the large leg veins— at or above the knee (e.g., the popliteal, femoral, and iliac veins) —is more serious because such thrombi more often embolize to the lungs and give rise to pulmonary infarction . DVTs are asymptomatic in approximately 50% of affected individuals and are recognised only in retrospect after embolisation . Common predisposing factors include: Bed rest and immobilisation Trauma Recent surgery (joint replacement especially) Trauma Obesity Malignancy Smoking OCP use Pregnancy and postpartum

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A: Increased PT. Correct for Acute DIC, but the best option is D for Chronic DIC. Option B: Increased aPTT. Correct for Acute DIC, but the best option is D for Chronic DIC. Option C: Decreased fibrinogen. Correct for Acute DIC, but the best option is D for Chronic DIC.

questions.text: For the action of heparin as an anticoagulant, availability of which chemical substance is mandatory?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Antithrombin-III Heparin per se does not possess any inherent anticoagulant action. Antithrombin-III is an endogenous anticoagulant plasma protein —acts as a “ Suicide substrate ” and neutralizes the action of certain key coagulation factors involved in intrinsic and common coagulation pathway. Binding of Heparin to Antithrombin-III accelerates the rate of neutralization of the activated factors (IIa, Xa, IXa, XIa and XIIa) by a 1000 fold. Hence, heparin exerts its anticoagulant effect indirectly through Antithrombin-III .

Highyeild:

Heparin Induced Thrombocytopenia (HIT) HIT syndrome is a serious, potentially life-threatening disorder that occurs following the administration of unfractionated heparin . Heparin is a Hapten, e. an incomplete antigen, and when it combines with Platelet Factor 4 (PF4) , it becomes a complete antigen and can lead to the formation of antibodies. PF4 usually is present on the platelet surface . The antibody then combines with this Heparin-PF4 complex on the platelet surface. This is followed by fibrin binding to this complex and forming a clot . This effect on platelets and endothelial damage induced by antibody binding combine to produce a prothrombotic state , even in the face of heparin administration and low platelet counts (as platelets are deposited in the thrombus thus formed). Thus there is Thrombocytopenia which is induced by heparin . This is seen after 4-14 days of heparin exposure .

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Thrombin. Incorrect . Option: B. Plasmin. Incorrect . Option: C. Thrombomodulin. Incorrect .

Extraedge:

Treatment of HIT: Heparin should be discontinued in such cases. Even low molecular weight (LMW) heparins are not safe in such patients, and they should be treated with a direct thrombin inhibitor. Drugs used in the treatment of HIT include: Bivalirudin Argatroban

questions.text: Abnormality in elastin protein can lead to all except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Fractures Abnormality in elastin protein can lead to various medical conditions, but fractures are not typically associated with elastin protein abnormalities. Elastin is a key component of connective tissues and is responsible for providing elasticity and resilience to tissues and organs. Mutations or deficiencies in elastin can result in structural abnormalities in different parts of the body.

Highyeild:

Elastin It is a connective tissue protein that is responsible for properties of extensibility and elastic recoil in tissues. It is present in large amounts, particularly in tissues that require these physical properties: Lung Blood vessels Elastic ligaments Small amounts in ear and skin It is encoded by the ELN gene. The gene encodes a protein that is one of the two components of elastic fibers. The encoded protein is rich in hydrophobic amino acids such as glycine and proline, which form mobile hydrophobic regions bounded by crosslinks between lysine residues. Abnormality in elastin protein can lead to abnormality in many systems Aortic aneurysm, joint laxity, and subluxation of lens. Other abnormalities include: Myopia, cataracts, retinal detachment, cutis laxa, diverticula of the small and large bowels, bronchiectasis, emphysema, cardiomegaly, congestive heart failure, murmurs, cor pulmonale.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B. Aortic aneurysm: Abnormalities in elastin can lead to weakening of the walls of the blood vessels, including the aorta, resulting in an increased risk of aortic aneurysm formation. Option C. Joint laxity: Elastin plays a role in maintaining the integrity and stability of joints. Abnormal elastin can contribute to joint laxity or hypermobility, where the joints have increased range of motion and can be prone to dislocations. Option D. Subluxation of lens: Elastin is a component of the suspensory ligaments that hold the lens of the eye in place. Elastin abnormalities can result in weakened or disrupted ligaments, leading to subluxation or dislocation of the lens.

questions.text: A Factory worker was working in a factory for the past 20 years, and now presenting with pleural thickening and fibrosis. Histopathology of the lesion is shown in the below image. What would be the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Asbestosis The given clinical scenario and histopathological image showing ferruginous bodies ( Golden -brown fusiform rods resembling dumbbells) suggests the diagnosis of Asbestosis . It is a lung disease caused by prolonged exposure to asbestos fibers . It commonly affects individuals who have worked in industries such as construction, mining, and insulation, where asbestos exposure is prevalent.

Asbestosis Associated with shipbuilding, roofing, plumbing Gross: Ivory-white sub-diaphragmatic and pleural plaques are pathognomonic. Histopathology: ferruginous bodies Increased risk of pleural effusion Affects lower lobes Causes: Lung cancer (Adenocarcinoma > SCC): 10-20 years exposure Mesothelioma : 20 to 40 years exposure

Option C .Coal Worker Pneumoconiosis: It primarily affects coal miners and is characterized by the accumulation of coal dust in the lungs, resulting in nodular opacities on imaging. Option D .Silicosis: It is caused by exposure to crystalline silica, commonly seen in workers involved in mining, construction, and sandblasting. Silicosis typically presents with nodular opacities and does not directly cause pleural thickening.

Alcian blue Alcian blue is a special stain commonly used to detect and visualize acidic mucins in tissues. Acidic mucins are a type of glycoprotein that contains sialic acid and sulfate residues. When tissues are stained with Alcian blue, it selectively binds to acidic mucins, resulting in a blue or turquoise color. This staining technique is particularly useful in identifying mucin-producing cells and structures, such as goblet cells in the gastrointestinal tract or mucous glands in respiratory tissues.
